info.name: Bitex API Reference
info.description:
# There are API guides too!


This is barebones API reference. If you're starting with a new integration, you should [head to the guides first](https://bitex-la.github.io/bitex-guides).

Did we forget to document something? Are we missing a field or resource you need? Is our API confusing? Please let us know at [developers@bitex.la](mailto:developers@bitex.la).

item.name: Market

request.description: Experimental endpoint: This endpoint may not be supported in further releases of the API. If your integration relies on it, please contact us at developers@bitex.la explaining your use case, in order to provide you with better support.

header.name: Cache-Control
header.description: Tells all caching mechanisms from server to client whether they may cache this object. It is measured in seconds

header.name: Content-Type
header.description: The mime type of this content

header.name: ETag
header.description: An identifier for a specific version of a resource, often a message digest

header.name: Set-Cookie
header.description: an HTTP cookie

header.name: Transfer-Encoding
header.description: The form of encoding used to safely transfer the entity to the user. Currently defined methods are: chunked, compress, deflate, gzip, identity.

header.name: X-Content-Type-Options
header.description: The only defined value, "nosniff", prevents Internet Explorer from MIME-sniffing a response away from the declared content-type

header.name: X-Frame-Options
header.description: Clickjacking protection: "deny" - no rendering within a frame, "sameorigin" - no rendering if origin mismatch

header.name: X-Request-Id
header.description: Custom header

header.name: X-Runtime
header.description: Custom header

header.name: X-XSS-Protection
header.description: Cross-site scripting (XSS) filter

request.description:
Get the ticker of a market.
See [List Tickers](#5760b8e3-6358-4b41-8217-66d3b0d53e8b) for possible :orderbook_code values.

request.description:
Get full information of market.


If you want only some of the fields provided, you can specify which fields to include by using the `include` query param. Possible values are: `bids`, `asks`, `transactions` and `candles`.

See the example to get only the orderbook data (bids and asks).

If you require more information other than the default, take a look at the endpoints `/api/markets/:orderbook_code/transactions` and `/api/markets/:orderbook_code/candles` respectively.

To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec).

query.description:
Market from which you want to retrieve data. If no orderbook_code is specified, all markets are retrieved.
To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec)

request.description:
Experimental endpoint: This endpoint may not be supported in further releases of the API. If your integration relies on it, please contact us at developers@bitex.la explaining your use case, in order to provide you with better support.
Get all transactions of a given market. The response items have the following structure: ``` [ 1542807208, //Timestamp 3, //ID 124, //Price 0.07064516 //Amount ] ``` (The structure is not jsonapi compliant, in order to reduce bandwidth and to easily export it to a file.) To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec)

query.description:
Market from which you want to retrieve data. If no `orderbook_code` is specified, all markets are retrieved.
To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec)
Number of days from where you want the candles to be. __default = 1__
Timespan (in hours) for each candle. __default = 1__

request.description: Get candles for a given market.

response.name: Show Market Candles for all Orderbooks

item.description:
Our public market data endpoints let anyone check our market's volume, prices and transaction history. It also provides aggregateted candlestick-like data points for customizable periods.

You don't need an API key (or even sign up to Bitex) to access the public market data.

item.name: Trading

request.description:
Possible status:

* `pending`: The bid has not been processed yet.
* `executing`: The bid is processed and could be matched.
* `completed`: The bid has been matched completely.
* `to_cancel`: You requested the cancellation but it can still be matched if a matching ask was sent previously.
* `cancelled`: The bid is cancelled and will not receive more matches.

query.description: The market in where to search the bids.

request.description: To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec)

To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec)

**Important note**: The amount of a bid is the amount of **Fiat (quote currency)** to spend. E.g: In the BTC/USD market, the bid amount is the amount of USD to spend in buying BTC.

This action represents an intention to cancel a Bid. Despite of this endpoint responding with a 204 status, the Bid may not have been cancelled if it was previously matched. In order to check the status of the bid, you can query all your active orders with the `/api/orders` endpoint.

Possible status:

* `pending`: The ask has not been processed yet.
* `executing`: The ask is processed and could be matched.
* `completed`: The ask has been matched completely.
* `to_cancel`: You requested the cancellation but it can still be matched if a matching bid was sent previously.
* `cancelled`: The ask is cancelled and will not receive more matches.

query.description: The market in where to search the bids.

request.description: To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec)

response.name: List Asks for only one orderbook

request.description:
To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec)

**Important note**: The amount of an ask is the amount of **Crypto (base currency)** to sell. E.g: In the BTC/USD market, the ask amount is the amount of BTC to be sold for USD.

This action represents an intention to cancel an Ask. Despite of this endpoint responding with a 204 status, the Ask may not have been cancelled if it was previously matched. In order to check the status of the ask, you can query all your active orders with the `/api/orders` endpoint.

request.description:
A buying bot is an assistant that puts Buy orders for you. It uses a strategy of dividing the amount and making the orders smaller, to get the best price.

* `amount`: The amount of __quote__ money that you intend to spend buying __base__ money. Both the __quote__ and the __base__ currencies are determined by the Orderbook selected. (e.g. A buying bot with amount = 100 and orderbook = BTC/USD, will spend 100 dollars in buying as much BTC as it can).


To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec)

request.description:
A selling bot is an assistant that puts Sell orders for you. It uses a strategy of dividing the amount and making the orders smaller, to get the best price.

* `amount`: The amount of __base__ money that you intend to sell for __quote__ money. Both the __quote__ and the __base__ currencies are determined by the Orderbook selected. (e.g. A selling bot with amount = 2 and orderbook = BTC/USD, will sell 2 BTC for as much USD as it can).

To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec)

item.description:
Trading Bots can manage a Bitcoin sale or buy to help you get a better pricing than you would get if you executed the full amount in a single order. 

The strategy used by bots is rather simple: They split up the amount to buy or sell in chunks of a given size and place orders at the best market price. 

Orders are spaced by time_to_live seconds to allow for new buyers and sellers to replenish the orderbook before executing again. Orders will be cancelled after time_to_live seconds if still executing. 

Bots also make sure to prevent executing in low-liquidity conditions: they will not place new orders if the spread between the best Bid and the best Ask is over 10 USD.

__Bots do not check or lock funds! If your robot fails to place an order because of insufficient funds or other, then it will be terminated prematurely. You'll find the termination reason in exit_status.__

query.description:
Market where the buys were done.
To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec)
Number of *days ago* from which the buys were done.
Max amount of buys to list.

Market where the sells were done.
To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec)
Number of *days ago* from which the sells were done.
Max amount of sells to list.

request.description: To get all possible `orderbook_code`s check [Orderbooks](#274fb149-0603-4d41-af61-2f1a0f438aec)
Lists all your bids and asks that are currently live in the orderbooks.

item.name: Deposit

query.description: Date from which to take the withdrawals. Fromat is ISO 8601 (YYYY-MM-DD)

request.description:
- `cost` is the amount taken from your deposit by third-party institutions (such as banks and/or the government)
- `fee` is the amount taken by the local digital wallet associated to your Bitex account.
- `amount` is the amount received, which is the same as `net_amount`. The `gross_amount` is the result of adding the `net_amount`, the `fee` and the `cost`.

response.name: List Cash Deposits

request.description:

- `fee` is the amount taken by the local digital wallet associated to your Bitex account.
- `amount` is the amount received, which is the same as `net_amount`. The `gross_amount` is the result of adding the `net_amount`, the `fee` and the `cost`.

request.description: It is not necessary to announce Cash deposits unless Bitex requires it for your integration. Usually we will credit your deposits when they show up in our bank account.

item.description:
These endpoints are for loading balance in your Bitex account.

For loading BTC you should get your [Coin Wallet](#abea0469-f651-460b-ba60-352fa673783b) and send your BTC to the address displayed there. Please note that if you send the BTC to your "auto_sell_address", that balance will be sold automatically in the exchange at the best price, and you will receive USD in your account.

If you want to load Fiat balance (such as USD, ARS, CLP, PYG or UYU), we provide an [experimental endpoint](#7345f816-e2db-4a29-b9d2-8c9d8e432a82) to get all the information you need to make the transfer. It's in HTML format, for it to be displayed in a browser and read by a human.

request.description: These instructions are created along with the Cash Withdrawal if it does not exist previously.

**Important note**: Provide all the information that is required for the applicable regulations. Some values might be accepted by the API but the withdrawal will be rejected afterwards in case there is an issue (such as missing or incorrect data). We can not validate that the data is correct and enough until the moment the withdrawal is processed. **Providing wrong/missing information may result in extra costs for you**.
Also remember that we can only process withdrawals to bank accounts belonging to **the same holder** as the Bitex account.

There are several withdrawal methods, using domestic bank transfers in supported countries, or international wire transfers if a domestic bank transfer is not available.

See the examples for the fields needed for each country.

item.description: These represent funds moving between your Exchange and Concierge balances, or between different users Concierge balances.

item.name: Merchant

response.name: List Payments
List Payments

request.description:
Possible `status` value:

* `pending`: Just created.
* `seen`: The expected_quantity is in transit.
* `done`: The expected_quantity was received.
* `settled`: Funds were credited to your balance
* `expired`: Payment was not seen before expiration date.
* `cancelled`: Payment was seen but didn't confirm for 2 hours, due to unknown or unexpected circumstances.

response.name: Show Payment

request.description:
Send us an amount and currency, and we'll quote it in bitcoin and give you an address where the payment is expected. The bitcoins will credit to your Bitex account and can be sold automatically to get the original amount in your requested currency.

Payments have an expiration of 1 hour, the bitcoin transaction must be initiated within that timeframe, if your customer takes longer you can always create a new payment and get a new quote and bitcoin address. If someone pays to an address after the payment is expired the bitcoin quantity will still be credited to your Bitex account, so it's possible for you to issue a refund and/or forward the received bitcoin to a new payment address yourself.

At the moment, the payments are only accepted in BTC and are transferred to the merchant in USD (unless he keeps 100% in BTC), no matter the amount or the currency specified in the payment.

* `amount`: Amount that the customer should pay.
* `currency_code`: Payment currency. One of [`BTC`, `USD`, `ARS`, `UYU`, `CLP`, `PYG`]
* `keep`: Percentage of the received money to keep in BTC instead of converting it to USD.
* `callback_url`: You can provide a `callback_url` to get notifications about a payment. When a `callback_url` is set for a payment Bitex will POST updates to it everytime a payment status changes.Your callback_url must be HTTPS because we want to make sure we're only contacting you, and it will include your first active API key in it, so that you know it's us sending the callback. Your API key is our shared secret, so you may want to handle it the same way you handle your users login credentials, hiding it from web server request logs for example. Our request's content type will be `application/json` and the content will be a structure containing your API key and the payment as it would be returned when querying its status.
* `customer_reference`: A customer-facing reference to show in the Point of Sale.
* `merchant_reference`: A sale reference for the merchant, generally to identify the sale.

response.name: Create Payment

request.description:
This endpoint should be use both for creating and updating the POS and it includes all default configurations for the payments to be received.

* `merchant_keep`: Percentage to keep in BTC instead of converting them to USD.

item.description:
Our Merchants API lets you accept bitcoin without worrying about the inner workings of the bitcoin Price and the bitcoin Network.

You just tell us the amount to charge in the customer's currency and we'll quote the bitcoin equivalent and set up a unique Bitcoin Address for the bitcoin to be sent to. Each payment corresponds to a different bitcoin address.

You can send bitcoin addresses via email, show them in your checkout using your own UI libraries, or easier yet: You can setup your own Bitex powered point of sale and use the user friendly Payment's Page.

All Bitcoins received as payment will be sold automatically at the best BTC/USD market price in Bitex. You can optionally decide to keep part of the received Bitcoin and withdraw or sell them at a later date.

Both USD and/or BTC received as payment will be credited to your Bitex Balance and can be withdrawn as per our supported cash-out methods.

Payments which are too small for our orderbook (roughly 2 USD or less) will not be settled automatically. They will be kept as bitcoin in your balance and it's up to you to decide when to sell them.

Contact us if you need settlements in currencies other than BTC or USD; if you need to have a guaranteed price instead of settling at the best BTC/USD price; or if you need to automatically settle lots of micro-payments.

item.description: Experimental endpoints: These endpoint may not be supported in further releases of the API. If your integration relies on them, please contact us at developers@bitex.la explaining your use case, in order to provide you with better support.

item.name: Users

request.description:
List all the Users you manage, and their associated Account information.
You can always manage at least *one* user which is yourself. If you have Master User permissions, you'll be able to manage more.

variable.description: The id of the User you want to retrieve. The special string 'me' will retrieve yourself.

request.description:
A User also has one Account, where you can check their balance in all supported currencies as well as their Monthly Statements for download.

You'll find a User's Account in the `included` section of the response.

You can provide the User id of any User you manage. If you want to check your own balance, you can use the special 'me' id and it will show your own data.

variable.description: The ID of the user you want to change.  The special id 'me' can be used to update your own data.

request.description: **Important**: The email change will not take effect immediately. Only after it is confirmed (clicking in a link we send to the new email address) you will be able to see the change reflected.
This endpoint is deprecated, when you Show or List a User you'll receive their accounts in the 'included' section of the response.

response.name: Show Account Information

item.description: See the [User Management Guide](https://api.bitex.la/docs/users/welcome/) for more information on these endpoints.

item.name: Compliance
Issues

request.description: When you finish adding `Seeds` to an `Issue` you announce it's complete so our compliance officers can review it.

item.description:
`Issues` belong to a `Person`, which in turn may have many `Issues`.

`Issues` have a __reason_code__ to help distinguish their motive: **new_client**, used for the `Person's` first `Issue`, or **further_clarification** for the ones after that.

`Issues` hold different types of `Seeds`, which have the actual customer data in them.

item.name: Seeds

request.description: The identification should be checked by an attachment demonstrating its validity.
The identification should be checked by an attachment demonstrating its validity.
The domicile should be checked by an attachment demonstrating its validity.
The domicile should be checked by an attachment demonstrating its validity.

Attachments include a full base64 encoded version of the file as the __document__ attribute.

We accept the following file types:

    'image/bmp',
    'image/jpeg',
    'image/jpg',
    'image/gif',
    'image/png'
    'application/pdf',
    'application/zip',
    'application/x-rar-compressed'


Keep in mind just changing the extension won't work, if the file format you want to send is not supported, put it in a zip or rar and upload that.

item.description:
Seeds collectively can contain all the information we require from you in order to make due dilligence and accept a customer.

At the API level, most values for seeds are valid.

Which seeds to submit, how many, and the fields to use, will depend on the compliance program that applies to the specific account, which you should have been informed about already.

If in doubt, just contact us.

Bitex needs to make some due dilligence on every customer, direct or indirect, according to our compliance program.

These endpoints can be used to share a customer's data with Bitex.

Learn more about the compliance API workflow in the [user management guides](https://api.bitex.la/docs/users/welcome/).

request.description: To learn more about our [port analogy](https://api.bitex.la/docs/cross_border/ports/)

item.name: Request
Request Webhooks
item.description: You can get push updates about your Request status instead of polling.

request.description:
Start by creating a new request. You would usually follow by adding outputs to it.

`port_code` is the place you're sending from. To know all the available ports (origin and destination) you can reffer to [ our port guide](https://api.bitex.la/docs/concierge/ports/)

`external_id` is optional, it should be this Request's id in your system. You should still store Bitex's Request id in your database.

`payment_authorization_code` is optional. Requests can be funded from your Bitex balance, but if you choose to make a specific payment to fund this request, you should fill in the `payment_authorization_code` with the payment clearing information so that we can identify it.

response.name: Create a Concierge Request

request.description:
You can set the `external_id` and `payment_authorization_code` when updating a request.

Keep in mind once set, these values cannot be changed.
Here you can look for a specific [concierge request](https://api.bitex.la/docs/concierge/request/)

response.name: Create Support Ticket
